bibl.title: 1825 Oct. 1, Nashville [Tennessee, to] James Winchester, Cairo [Tennessee] / J[ohn] W. Overton
bibl.author: Overton, J[ohn] W.
bibl.note: This is a letter from Judge John Overton to General James Winchester, dated October 1, 1825. Overton writes about a recent trip he took with General and Mrs. Jackson. He writes about some law suits that he and Winchester are working on. Overton also wants to know if Winchester received a deed he sent him.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 2.1 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div1.p: Last night I returned to this place from the western Districts, to which place I went in company with Genl Jackson & his lady. Mrs Jackson went to the neighbourhood of Jackson in Madison County , to visit her only two surviving sisters

The Genl was invited to partake of a public dinner at Paris in Henry County, which detained us a week longer than I expected, and kept me from leaving here on the 29th as I expected you will therefore have to give Mr Bledsoe another notice, so that I may attend which I will do on being informed of the time

I could very much wish
that you could spend a day at my house__ or a week if convenient, in order that we may talk over your law business particularly the suit with Walton

The Donelson suit I am master of__ I am not sure that I am of the other At all events it would be of great service to the cause to talk it over, examining each point critically__ This is the universal practise with Lawyers & their clients __ Writing is not sufficient At all times you Know me well enough to be convincd that every exertion will be made on my part

I transmitted you a deed for your interest in the Ramsey tract Have you received it if so please acknowledge the receipt
of it by letter_ and as the deed discharges the obligation you hold of mine, it is nothing but right that you should deliver up that obligation to me, sending it by mail or safe private conveyance as soon as you can. Being in years less uncertain, it is my wish that no obligations should lie out, case of death__ I presume you omitted to send it by when you last wrote to me. I therefore expect to hear from you on this subject, being the only obligation I have out in the world
Present me to Mr & Mrs Breedlove, of whose polite attention when at orleans I retain a dull sense

closer.add:
Replied to 5th Oct
1825
concerning taking
deposition &c
Walton Case
